data.title: Black–Scholes model
data.meta_description: The Black-Scholes model is a pricing model widely used in the valuation of European-style options. On this page you can find a range of resources on the model and the issues surrounding it.
data.text:
What is the Black-Scholes model, and how is it used?

The Black-Scholes model, also known as the Black-Scholes-Merton model, is a mathematical model of financial derivative markets. It was developed in the early-1970s by economists Fischer Black and Myron Scholes, with contributions from Robert Merton.

The model serves as the basis for the Black-Scholes formula, which is widely used to calculate the theoretical price of European-style options – ie, those which are exercisable only at a specific single future date.

In its standard form, the Black-Scholes formula has five parameters, each representing a particular asset dynamic or aspect of market conditions. These are: the price of the underlying stock, the option's strike price, the time until expiration, the risk-free interest rate, and the expected stock price volatility. If using the Merton modification, there is a sixth input, namely the level of the maintainable dividend on a continuously compounding basis.

Due to its solid foundation as a mathematical proof, the Black-Scholes model has served as the basis for several other models and formulae, created by other academics for alternative uses. Examples include Margrabe's formula for currency futures, and various put option models used for measuring a lack of liquidity. International Valuation Standards advocate for the use of option models when valuing certain categories of complex share classes.

Black-Scholes option pricing in Excel

In practice, the Black-Scholes option pricing model is often used within a spreadsheet. There are various ‘ready-made’ Black-Scholes spreadsheets available on the internet, as well as numerous resources which explain how to create an option pricing spreadsheet incorporating the Black-Scholes formula (including some of the eBook chapters listed below). If using such a spreadsheet, you should take care to ensure that it faithfully replicates the formula, and that it is appropriate for your purposes. Here, it might be helpful to check its output against another internet source.

The Library enquiry team can provide ICAEW members, ACA students and registered ICAEW affiliates with an example Black-Scholes spreadsheet, though it should be noted that this spreadsheet is not approved by ICAEW. For more information, please contact us on +44 (0)20 7920 8620, or email library@icaew.com.

eBooks

The Library & Information Service provides a collection of eBooks as a benefit of membership. Please log in to access these titles. If you are unable to access an eBook, please see our Help and support or contact library@icaew.com.

Exclusive Analysis of Black–Scholes

This chapter begins with an examination of various ways of measuring and forecasting volatility. It then moves on to test the validity of the Black–Scholes equation, and assess the limitations of the equation for pricing European options.

Exclusive Black-Scholes-Merton option pricing model

A section providing a simplified, easy-to-read explanation of the Black-Scholes-Merton option pricing model.

Exclusive Black–Scholes model

A chapter outlining how the Black–Scholes formula is used to price European calls and puts. Includes a discussion of delta hedging, as well as an explanation of implied volatility and its use in options trading.

Exclusive Black–Scholes model in Microsoft Excel

A section setting out how the Black–Scholes model may be used in Microsoft Excel spreadsheets. Includes screenshots showing example sheets and their workings.

Exclusive Examining the binomial and Black-Scholes pricing models

A chapter examining three widely used methods for pricing options: the binomial tree, the Black-Scholes equation, and the Monte Carlo simulation.

Exclusive Introduction to valuing stock options

A chapter providing an overview of some models and techniques commonly used in the valuation of options, including the Black–Scholes model, the binomial model, and Monte Carlo simulation techniques.

Exclusive Partial differential equations

A chapter providing a brief primer on the analysis and solution of partial differential equations. Includes a consideration of the meaning of terms in the Black–Scholes equation.

Exclusive Quantitative finance for dummies

A simple, step-by-step guide to various key aspects of quantitative finance. It is intended to give readers a solid understanding of futures, options and risk, and to help them to get up-to-speed on the most popular equations, methods, formulas and models (such as the Black-Scholes model) that are applied in the field.

Bloomsbury Accounting and Tax Service

Eligible firms have free access to Bloomsbury Professional's comprehensive online library, comprising around 80 titles from some of the country's leading tax and accounting subject matter experts. Find out who is eligible and how you can access the Accounting and Tax Service.

Exclusive Using option-pricing models

A section on the use of option-pricing models when accounting for equity awards to employees. Includes coverage of the Black–Scholes model and the binomial model.

Online articles

Foundational texts

Exclusive The pricing of options and corporate liabilities

The classic article in which Fischer Black and Myron Scholes first set out their theoretical valuation formula for options.

Exclusive The valuation of option contracts and a test of market efficiency

A foundational paper in the theory of option valuation, in which Fischer Black and Myron Scholes test their famous formula, comparing the option values derived from it with actual premiums on option contracts.

Theory of rational option pricing

Classic article in which Robert Merton builds upon the seminal option pricing theory developed by Fischer Black and Myron Scholes, deriving additional formulae. Registration is required for access.

Selected recent commentary

Exclusive On the performance of the Black and Scholes options pricing formulas during the subprime and Covid‐19 crises

An investigation of the performance of Black–Scholes option pricing formulae during two periods of market stress. The authors argue that the accuracy of these formulae is very poor.

Exclusive Employee stock options and the flawed use of the Black–Scholes option pricing model

An examination of the use of the Black–Scholes model in financial reporting. The authors present evidence to suggest that the flawed use of the model leads to errors in reporting, most notably with regard to earnings.
